text: I'm not the same kind of the person like
six months ago and I think that the
situation it is same among the new
generation of Hong Kong hundreds of
children who were way too young to
actually be studying here at the
university found themselves trapped on
campus we saw their head teachers
pleading to be allowed in so that they
could try and bring them out to safety
so the question is why are so many kids
risking so much safety but I'm more
worried about my future about Hong
Kong's future about what city are we
going to live in the future if we are
living in a safe city but we've stopped
freedom and democracy people cannot do
what they want to do people cannot think
what they want you think
I have seen kids you know they cannot
really concentrate on their schoolwork
so which is quite alarming I would say
I've seen kids dropping the academic
performance significantly and then they
cannot ready for sleep at night they you
know scroll down their phone late until
2 or 3 a.m. and then so they get sick
more often when you're in the
Polytechnic University you're all
trapped what went through your mind at
that point I still remember the fear in
the campus I was having my breakfast and
suddenly I cried because I thought about
what's happening in the future we are we
put in jail for 10 years where I've been
not able to see my friends anymore
my parents my teachers someone who care
about me I find that some of the kids
are they are changing the way to deal
with this collective trauma they're
trying to integrate the movement into
the daily life in the long term you'll
find that this particular generation of
kids will be quite different from other
developed countries because you know the
mistrust on the government stress on the
police mistrust on the systems that
could be quite alarming
you
